title: Doorstep parcel thefts rise by a quarter in the last two years
text:
The number of parcel thefts from Britain's doorsteps has risen by nearly a quarter in the last two years, new data claims.

There have been 2,578 thefts reported to 23 police forces across the country since April 2016, according to data obtained under the Freedom of Information Act by iParcelBox, a parcel delivery website.

In the period of April 2016/17, there were 786 recorded thefts. This jumped to 962 in 2018/19 – an increase of 22 per cent.

This is likely to be the tip of the iceberg, as many thefts go unreported and little more than half of police forces responded to the FOI request.

Amazon Crime: There were 2,578 parcel thefts that were reported to 23 police forces across the country

The area with the highest level of stolen parcels - of the forces that responded - was found to be Lancashire Constabulary, which reported 292 thefts in the last three years with 108 taking place in the last 12 months.

The research also revealed that the West Country is a hotspot for parcel crime with 20 per cent of all thefts coming from this area.

Devon and Cornwall Police reported 264 thefts in total, with 91 taking place in the last year whilst Avon and Somerset Police revealed it had 262 incidents of stolen packages in total.

Leicestershire Police also said they had 216 thefts reported over the three year period, closely followed by West Midlands Police which had 211 incidents.

Surrey Police has also seen an increase in parcel thefts from 46 in 2017 to 2018 to 55 in 2018 to 2019 - a total of 153 in the last three years.

Meanwhile, the area with the lowest number of parcel theft came from the South Wales Police who had no reported thefts in the last three years.

The Ministry of Defence police came close behind with just five thefts in the last three years.

This is likely due to the fact the Ministry of Defence Police is a civilian special police force which is part of the United Kingdom's Ministry of Defence and only works on specific cases.

Nottinghamshire Constabulary was also low on numbers with only 21 accounts of parcel theft – accounting for just one per cent of the total figures.

Durham Constabulary also had low levels of stolen packages recording only 28 reports of theft and North Wales Police only had 34 incidents.

Paul Needler, founder of iParcelBox, said: 'It's clear that the online shopping surge is fuelling a new crimewave of parcel thefts across the UK.

'For opportunistic thieves, the chance to steal an unattended parcel that is sitting on the doorstep is irresistible.

'Asking the delivery driver to place your package under a flowerpot or behind your wheelie bin when you're out should no longer be an option.

'Instead, it's vital that all online shoppers ensure they have a secure, easy to use, delivery box in place to receive their parcels.'
